thread.title: Man City lucky to draw with Huddersfield as Pep Guardiola prepares for first cup replay of his managerial career
thread.title_full: Man City lucky to draw with Huddersfield as Pep Guardiola prepares for first cup replay of his managerial career

author: Simon Mullock
title: Man City lucky to draw with Huddersfield as Pep Guardiola prepares for first cup replay of his managerial career
text:
Sport Opinion Man City lucky to draw with Huddersfield as Pep Guardiola prepares for first cup replay of his managerial career City's players just didn't seem to fancy it in windy conditions and on a lively pitch with even livelier opponents Share Pep Guardiola endured a frustrating day in Yorkshire (Photo: Gareth Copley) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
When Pep Guardiola was taking history lessons on Manchester City last summer, he must have skipped the class on FA Cup upsets. 
City have suffered plenty of pain down the years and names like Shrewsbury, Halifax, Notts County, Oldham and Wigan are writ large on the club's roll of dishonour. 
That Huddersfield Town didn't add to the Blues' catalogue of woes had little to do with their decorated Catalan coach. 
Guardiola sent out a team of eight changes at the John Smith's Stadium with Tuesday night's Champions League with Monaco in mind – and then got lucky. Very lucky. 
Huddersfield deserved at least a replay at the Etihad on Tuesday week. In fact, with a little good fortune they would now be in the quarter-finals. Huddersfield were good value for their draw against City (Photo: REUTERS) David Wagner's side performed far more determinedly than Pep Guardiola's (Photo: AFP) 
Terriers boss David Wagner said: “We had two or three chances – and one very good chance. 
“That we have created those chances against one of the best teams in Europe, so I am very happy. 
“We stuck to our own identity. We were aggressive and we were brave – and that makes me very proud. 
“I am happy to have the rematch in a great environment like the Etihad. 
“Like all football matches, I don't know if we will win, but I believe that we can go to Manchester and perform.” View gallery 
Huddersfield, of course, are no lower division whipping boys. 
And Wagner himself made seven team changes as he looks towards this week's crucial Championship clash with Reading. 
The difference was that the home side attacked the occasion. 
In contrast City's players just didn't seem to fancy it in windy conditions and on a lively pitch with even livelier opponents. City's players weren't up for the fight at the John Smith's Stadium (Photo: Getty) City's draw against Huddersfield means they must negotiate a replay (Photo: Laurence Griffiths) 
Roared on by a crowd of 24,129 – a record for a football match at the John Smith's Stadium – Huddersfield got on the front foot and stayed there. 
The lively Rajiv Van La Parra fired a great early chance straight at Claudio Bravo. 
But the home side had an escape when Nolito's toe-poke was saved by Joel Coleman and Mark Hudson had to scramble Jesus Navas' follow-up off the line. 
City had possession; Huddersfield the chances. Jack Payne's free-kick was tipped over by Bravo and when the outstanding Philip Billing did fire into the roof of the net, it took an offside flag to wreck his celebration. Jack Payne's free-kick was tipped over by Claudio Bravo (Photo: REUTERS) Philip Billing thought he'd opened the scoring for the Terriers but the flag was up (Photo: REUTERS) 
Sergio Aguero came to life as half-time approached, exchanging passes with Fernandinho only to be denied by Coleman. 
And the Argentine threatened again after the break when he burst forward to unleash a low shot that Coleman was once again equal to. 
But it was City who were hanging on as the tie entered its final phase, especially after Wagner had sent on Nakhi Wells, Elias Kachunga and Izzy Brown. 
Even the introductions of Kevin De Bruyne and Leroy Sane couldn't spark the visitors to life. 
One sour note to the occasion was when a plastic coke bottle was thrown towards Raheem Sterling as he warmed up on the touchline in the second half. 
Afterwards Guardiola refused to comment on the incident but he did defend his selection policy as he looked forward to the first replay he's ever been involved in. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
